summary: This paper explores the use of machine learning algorithms to predict Parkinson's Disease (PD) using vocal parameters. It evaluates various algorithms' performance on a dataset to identify the most accurate one for predicting early stages of PD based on voice features.
relationships: Relationship between vocal parameters and Parkinson's Disease prediction accuracy
Dependency of algorithm performance on the nature and quality of vocal data
Interaction between machine learning models and classification accuracy in PD prediction
variables: average vocal fundamental frequency: A measure of the average pitch of voice used as a feature in PD prediction
maximum vocal fundamental frequency: The highest pitch recorded, used to analyze voice stability
minimum vocal fundamental frequency: The lowest pitch recorded, used to analyze voice stability
variation in fundamental frequency: Measures the fluctuations in voice pitch, important for detecting PD
variation in amplitude: Measures the fluctuations in voice loudness, used as a feature in PD detection
ratio of noise to tonal components: Used to determine the quality of voice and its degradation
health status: Binary indicator where 1 represents PD-infected and 0 represents healthy
nonlinear dynamical complexity measures: Used to analyze the complexity of voice signal patterns
Signal fractal scaling exponent: A measure of the fractal dimension of the voice signal
nonlinear measures of fundamental frequency variation: Used to assess the stability and variability of voice pitch
key_ideas: Utilization of vocal parameters as predictive features for Parkinson's Disease
Comparison and evaluation of various machine learning algorithms to find the most effective one for PD prediction
Implementation of a predictive model using machine learning to assess the likelihood of Parkinson's based on voice features
Future work includes direct application of voice inputs for real-time PD prediction and exploring other methods to increase accuracy
